title: Modified Fatigue Impact Scale (MFIS)
description: Measures the impact that fatigue has on patient's daily life across physical, cognitive, and psychosocial domains

result.name: mfis_total_score
result.description: Total MFIS score indicating overall fatigue impact on daily functioning

ranges.interpretation: Total score below 38 suggests fatigue impact that may not significantly affect quality of life. Continue routine monitoring and consider lifestyle interventions.
Total score of 38 or above indicates clinically significant fatigue impact on daily functioning. Consider comprehensive fatigue management strategies and regular monitoring.

references: Fisk JD, Ritvo PG, Ross L, Haase DA, Marrie TJ, Schlech WF. Measuring the functional impact of fatigue: initial validation of the fatigue impact scale. Clin Infect Dis. 1994 Jan;18 Suppl 1:S79-83. doi: 10.1093/clinids/18.supplement_1.s79.

Learmonth YC, Dlugonski D, Pilutti LA, Sandroff BM, Klaren R, Motl RW. Psychometric properties of the Fatigue Severity Scale and the Modified Fatigue Impact Scale. J Neurol Sci. 2013 Aug 15;331(1-2):102-7. doi: 10.1016/j.jns.2013.05.023.
formula: Sum of all 21 item scores. Physical subscale: items 4,6,7,10,13,14,17,20,21. Cognitive subscale: items 1,2,3,5,11,12,15,16,18,19. Psychosocial subscale: items 8,9.
notes: Originally developed for multiple sclerosis patients but used in various conditions
Each item scored 0-4: Never=0, Rarely=1, Sometimes=2, Often=3, Almost Always=4
Cutoff of 38 points recommended for clinically significant fatigue impact
Changes â‰¥4 points on MFIS predict significant effect on quality of life
Provides subscales for Physical (36 points max), Cognitive (40 points max), and Psychosocial (8 points max) functioning
Self-administered questionnaire taking 5-10 minutes to complete
21-item version recommended over 5-item version for comprehensive assessment
